title: F. O
body: B. In mercantlle contracts, thls abbrevlation means “free on board,” and lm-ports that the seller or consignor of goods will deliver them on the car, vessel, or oth-er conveyance by which they are to be trans-ported wlthout expense to the buyer or con-slgnee, that is, wlthout charge for packlng, crating, drayage, etc., untll dellvered to the carrier. Vogt v. Shlenbeck, 122 wls. 491, 100 N. W. 820, 67 L. R. A. 756, 106 Am. St. Rep. 989; SUberman v. Clark, 96 N. Y. 523; Sheffield Furnace Co. v. Hull Coal & Coke Co., 101 Ala. 446, 14 South. 672

title: Fabric Lands
body: In Engllsh law. Lands given towards the malntenance, re-bulldlng, or repairing of cathedral and other churches. Cowell; Blount

title: Fabrica
body: In old Engllsh law. The maklng or coining of money

title: Fabrioare
body: Lat To make. Used in old English law of a lawful coining, and also of an uniawful making or counterfeiting of coin. See 1 Salk. 342

title: Fabricate
body: To fabricate evidence is to arrange or manufacture drcumstances or indicia, after the fact commuted, wlth the purpose of using them as evldence, and of dcceitfully maklng them appear as lf accl-dental or undeslgned; to devlse falsely or contrlve by artlfice wlth the intention to de-celve. Such evldence may be wholly forged and artificial, or it may consist in so warplng and dlstortlng real facte as to create an erroneous lmpresslon in the minds of those who observe them and then presenting such lrn-pression as true and genulne

title: Fabula
body: In old European law. A con-tract or formal agreement; bnt particularly used in the Lombardic and Vlsigothlc laws to ienote a marriage contract or a will

title: Fac Simile
body: An exact copy, preserv-tng all the marks of the original

title: Fac Simile Probate
body: In England, where the construction of a wlll jnay be affected by the appearance of the original paper, the court wlll order the probate to pass in foe simile, as it may posslbly help to show the meanlng of the testator. 1 williams, Ex’rs, (7th Ed.) 331, 38G, 566

title: Face
body: The face of an instrument is that whlch is shown by the mere language employed, wlthout any explanation, modiflca-tlon, or addltlon from extrinsic facts or evi-dence. Thus, lf the express terms of the paper disclose a fatal legal defect, it is said to be “void on its face

title: Facers
body: Lab To do; to make. Thus, facere defaltam, to make default; facere duellum, to make the duel, or make or do battle; facere flnem, to make or pay a fine; facere legem, to make one's law; facere so-cramentum, to make oath

title: Facias
body: That you cause, occurring in the phrases “scire facias,” (that you cause to know,) "fieri facias," (that you cause to be made,) etc

title: Faciendo
body: In doing or paylng; in some activlty

title: Facies
body: Lat The face or countenance; the exterlor appearance or view; hence, con-templatlon or study of a thlng on lts external or apparent slde. Thus, prima facie menus at the first lnspection, on a preUmlnary or exterlor scrutiny, when we speak of a "prima facie case,” we mean one whlch, on lts own showlng, on a first examlnatlon, or wlthout investlgatlng any alleged defenses, is apparently good and maintalnable

title: Facile
body: In Scotch law. Easlly persuaded; easlly lmposed upon. Bell

title: Facilities
body: This name was formerly glven to certain notes of some of the banks in the state of Connecticut, which were made payable in two years after the close of the war of 1812. Sprlngfleld Bank v. Merrick, 14 Mass. 322

title: Facility
body: In Scotch law. Pllancy of dlsposition. Bell

title: Facio Ut Des
body: (Lat. I do that you may give.) A species of contract in the civil law (belng one of the innominate contracts) whlch occurs when a man agrees to perform anythlng for a prlce elther specifically mentioned or left to the determination of the law to set a value on It; as when a servant hires hlmself to hls master for certaln wages or an agreed sum of money. 2 BL Comm. 445

title: Facio Ut Facias
body: (Lat I do that you may do.) A specles of contract in the civil law (being one of the innominate con-tracts) whlch. occurs when I agree wlth a man to do hls work for him lf he wlll do mlne for me; or lf two persons agree to marry together, or to do any other positive acts on both sldes; or it may be to forbear on one side in conslderatlon of something done on the other. 2 Bl. Comm. 444

title: Fact
body: A thlng done; an actlon per-formed or an Incident transplring; an event or drcumstance; an actual occurrence

title: Facta
body: In old English law. Deeds. Facta armorum, deeds or feats of arms; that is, jousts or tournaments. Cowell

title: Factio Testamenti
body: In the civil law. The rlght, power, or capacity of mak-lng a wlll; called “factio acth-a" lnst. 2, 10, 6

title: Facto
body: In fact; by an act; hy the act or fact Ipso facto, by the act itself; hy the mere effect of a fact, without anything su-peradded, or any proceeding upon it to give it effect. 3 Kent, Comm. 55, 58

title: Factor
body: 1. A commercial agent, em-ployed by a principal to sell merchandise consigned to him for that purpose, for and in behalf of the principal, but usually in his own name, being intrusted with the posses* sion and control of the goods, and being remunerated by a commission, commonly called “factorage.” Howland v. woodruff, 60 N. Y. 80; In re Rabenau (D. C.) 118 Fed. 474; Lawrence v. Stonington Bank, 6 Conn. 527; Graham v. Duckwall, 8 Bush (Ky.) 17

title: Factoreeing Prooess
body: Itt American law. A process by which the effects of a debtor are attached in the hands of a third person. A term peculiar to the practice in Vermont and Connecticut otherwise termed “trustee process” and “garnishment” Cross ▼. Brown, 19 R. I. 220, 33 Atl. 147

title: Factory
body: In English law. The term Includes all buildings and premises wherein, or within the close or curtilage of which, steam, water, or any mechanical power is used to move or work any machinery employed in preparing, manufacturing, or flnish-lng cotton, wool, hair, silk, flax, hemp, jute, or tow. So defined by the statute 7 Vlct. c. 15, § 73. By later acts this definition has been extended to various other manufactur-ing places. Mozley & whitley

title: Factum
body: Lat in old English law

title: Faculties
body: In tbe law of divoree

title: Faculties, Court Of
body: In English ecclesiastical law. A jurisdiction or tribunal belonging to the archblshop. It does not hold pleas in any suits, but creates rights to pews, monuments, and particular places, and modes of burial. It has also various powers under 25 Hen. VIII. c. 21, in granting licenses of different descriptions, ns a license to marry, a faculty to erect an organ in a parish church, to level a church-yard, to re-move bodies previously burled. 4 Inst. 337

title: Faculty
body: In eoolesiastioal law. A

title: Faculty Of A College
body: The corps of professors, instructors, tutors, and lec-turers. To be distinguished from the board of trustees, who constitute the corporation

title: Faculty Of Advocates
body: The col-lege or society of advocates in Scotland

title: Faderfium
body: In old English law. A marriage gift coming from the father or brother of the bride

title: Fjeder-Feoh
body: In old English law. The portlon brought by a wife to her hus-band, and which reverted to a widow, in case the heir of her deceased husband refused his consent to her second marriage; i. e., it re-verted to her family in case she returned to them, wharton

title: Fjesting-Men
body: Approved men who were strong-armed; habentes homines or rich men, men of substance; pledges or bonds-men, who, by Saxon custom, were bound to answer for each other’s good behavior. Cow-ell; Du Cange

title: Faggot
body: A badge worn in popish times hy persons who had recanted and abjured what was then adjudged to be heresy, as an emblem of what they had merited. Cowell

title: Faggot Votes
body: A faggot vote is where a man is formally possessed of a right to vote for members of parliament, without possessing the substauce which the vote should represent; as if he is enabled to buy a property, and at the same moment mort-gage it to its full vaiue for the mere sake of the vote. Such a vote is called a “faggbt vote." See 7 & 8 wm. III. c. 25, S 7. whar-ton

title: Faida
body: In Saxon law. Malice; open and deadly hostility; deadly feud. The word designated the enmity between the family of a murdered man and that of his murderer, which was recognized, among the Teutonic peoples, as justification for vengeance taken by any one of the former upon any one of the latter

title: Fail
body: 1. The difference between “fall” and “refuse” is that the latter involves an act of the will, while the former may be an act of Inevitable necessity. Taylor v. Mason, 9 wheat. 344, 6 L. Ed. 101. See Stallings v. Thomas, 55 Ark. 326, 18 S. W. 184; Tele-graph Co. v. Irvin, 27 Ind. App. 62, 59 N. E. 327; Persons v. Hight, 4 Ga. 497

title: Faillite
body: In French law. Bankrupt-cy; failure; the situation of a debtor who finds himself unable to fulfill his engage-ments. Code de Com. arts. 442, 580; Civil Code La. art. 3522

title: Failure
body: In a general sense, deficiency, want, or lack; ineffectualness; inefficiency as measured by some legal standard; an un-successful attempt, white v. Pettijohn, 23 N. C. 55; State v. Butler, 81 Minn. 103, 83 N. W. 483; Andrews v. Keep, 38 Ala. 317

title: Faint Pleader
body: A fraudulent, false, or collusive manner of pleading to the de-ception of a third person

title: Fairly
body: Justly; rightly; equitably, wlth substantial correctness

title: Fait
body: L. Fr. Anything done. A deed; act; fact

title: Fait Enrolle
body: A deed enrolled, as a bargain and sale of freeholds. 1 Eeb. 568

title: Fait Juridique
body: In French law. A juridical fact one of the factors or ele-ments constitutive of an obligation

title: Faith
body: 1. Confidence; credit; reliance. Thus, an act may be said to be done “on the faith" of certain representations

title: Faithfully
body: As used in bonds of pub-lic aud private officers, this term imports not only honesty, but also a punctilious discharge of all the duties of the office, requiring com-petence, diligence, and attention, without any malfeasance or nonfeasance, aside from mere mistakes. State v. Chadwick, 10 or. 468; Hoboken v. Evans, 31 N. J. Law, 343; Har-ris v. Hanson, 11 Me. 245; American Bank' v. Adams, 12 Pick. (Mass.) 306; Union Bank v. Clossey, 10 Johns. (N. Y.) 273; Perry v. Thompson, 16 N. J. Law, 73

title: Fakir
body: A street peddler who disposes of worthless wares, or of any goods above thelr value, by means of any false representa-tion, trick, device, lottery, or game of chance. Mills' Ann. SL Colo. 8 1400

title: Faitours
body: Idle persons; idle livers; vagabonds. Cowell; Blount

title: Falang
body: In old English law. A Jack-*et or close coat Blount

title: Falcare
body: In old English law. To mow. Falcate prata, to mow or cut grass in mead-ows laid In for hay. A customary service1 to the lord by hls inferior tenants

title: Falcidia
body: In Spanish law. The Fal-cidian portion; the portion of an inheritance which could not be legally bequeathed away from the heir, viz., one-fourth

title: Falcidian Law
body: In Roman law. A law on the subject of testamentary disposi-tion, enacted by the people in the year of Rome 714, on the proposition of the tribune Falcidlus. By this law, the testator’s right to burden his estate with legacies was sub-jected to an important restriction. It pre-scribed that no one could bequeath more than three-fourths of his property in legacies, and that the heir should have at least one-fourth of the estate, and that, should the testator violate this prescript, the heir may have the right to make a proportional deduction from each legatee, so far as necessary. Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 771; Inst. 2, 22

title: Falcidian Portion
body: That portion of a testator’s estate which, by the Falcidian law, was required to be left to the heir,, amounting to at least one-fourth

title: Falda
body: or FALDA. A sheep-fold. Cow-eih

title: Falda
body: Span. In Spanish law. The slope or skirt of a hill. Fossat v. United States, 2 wall. 673, 17 L. Ed. 739

title: Falda Cursus
body: In old English law. A fold-course; the course (going or taking about) of a fold. Spelmau

title: Faldage
body: The privilege which anclent-ly several lords reserved to themselves of set-tiDg up folds for sheep in any fields within their manors, the better to manure them, and this not only with their own but their tenants’ sheep. Called, variously, “secta fal-dare,” “fold-course,” “free-fold," “faldagii." Cowell; Spelman

title: Faldata
body: In old English law. A flock or fold of sheep. Cowell

title: Faldfey
body: Sax. A fee or rent paid by a tenant to his lord for leave to fold his sheep on hls own ground. Blount

title: Faldisdory
body: In ecclesiastical law. The bishop’s seat or throne within the chan-. ceL

title: Faldsoca
body: Sax. The liberty or privi-iege of foldage

title: Faldstool
body: A place at the south side of the altar at which the sovereign kneels at his coronation, wharton

title: Faldworth
body: In Saxon law. A person of age that he may be reckoned of some decennary. Du Fresne

title: Falerje
body: ln old English law. The tackle and furniture of a cart or wain. Blount

title: Falesia
body: In old English law. A hill dr down by the sea-side. Co. Litt. 5b; Domesday

title: Falk-Land
body: See Folc-Land

title: Fall
body: In Scotch law. To lose. To fall from a right is to lose or forfeit it 1 Kames, Eq. 228

title: Fall Of Land
body: In English law. ,A quantity of land six ells square superficial measure

title: Fallo
body: In Spanish law. The final de-cree or judgment given in a controversy at law

title: Fallow-Land
body: Land plow’ed, but not sown, and left uncultivated for a time after successive crops

title: Fallum
body: In old English law. An un-explained term for some particular kind of land. Cowell

title: Falsa Demonstratio
body: In the civil law. False designation; erroneous descrip

title: Falsa Moneta
body: In the clvll law. False or counterfeit money. Cod. 9, 24

title: Falsare
body: In old Engllsh law. To counterfeit. Quia falsavit sigillum, because he counterfeited the seal. Bract fol. 276b

title: Falsartus
body: A counterfeiter. Townsh, Pl. 260

title: False
body: Untrue; erroneous; deceitful; contrived or calculated to deceive and in-jure. Unlawful. In law, this word means something more than untrue; it means something designedly untrue and deceitful, and implies an intention to perpetrate some treachery or fraud. Hatcher v. Dunn, 102 Iowa, 411, 71 N. W. 343, 36 L. R. A. 689; Mason v. Association, 18 U. C. C. P. 19; Ratterman v. Ingalls, 48 ohio St. 468, 28 N. E. 168

title: Falsedad
body: In Spanish law. Falsity; an alteration of the truth. Las Partidas, pt. 3, tlt 26, 1. 1

title: Falsehood
body: A statement or assertion known to be untrue, and intended to deceive. X willful act or declaration contrary to the truth. Putnam v. osgood, 51 N. H. 207

title: Falsi Crimen
body: EN. Fraudulent suboma-tlon or concealment, with design to darken or hide the truth, and make things appear otherwise than they are. It is committed (1) by words, as when a witness swears falsely; (2) by writing, as when a person antedates a contract; (3) by deed, as sell-lug by false weights and measures, whar-ton. See Ckimen Falsi

title: Falsification
body: In equity practice. The showing an item in the debit of an account to be either wholly false or in some part erroneous. 1 Story, Eq. Jur. § 525. And see Phillips v. Belden, 2 Edw. Ch. 23; Pit v. Choiinondeley, 2 Ves. Sr. 565; Kennedy v. Adickes, 37 S. C. 174, 15 S. E. 922; Tate v. Gairdner, 119 Ga. 133, 46 S. E. 73

title: Falsify
body: To disprove; to prove to be false or erroneous; to avoid or defeat; spok-en of verdicts, appeals, etc

title: Falsifying A Record
body: A high of-fense against public justice, punishable ip England by 24 & 25 Vict. c. 98, §§ 27. 28. and in thetUnited States, generally, by stat-ute.

title: Falsing
body: In Scotch law. False making ; forgery. "Falsing of evid ent is." 1 Pltc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 85

title: Falso Retorno Brevium
body: A

title: Falsonarius
body: A forger; a counterfeiter. Hov. 424

title: Falsus
body: Lat. False; fraudulent; erroneous. Deceitful; mlstaken

title: Fama
body: Lat Fame; character; reputa-tion; report of common opinion

title: Famacide
body: A killer of reputation; a slanderer

title: Familia
body: In Roman law. A house* hold; a family, on the composition of the Roman family, see Aonati; Coon ati; and see Mackeld. Rom. Law, I 144

title: Families Emptor
body: In Roman law. An Intermediate person who purchased the aggregate lnheritance when sold per ms ei libram, in the process of making a will un-der the Twelve Tables. This purchaser was merely a man of straw, transmitting the In-heritance to the hares proper. Brown

title: Familiares Regis
body: Persons of the klng’s household. The ancient title of the “six clerks” of chancery In England. Crabb, Com. Law, 184; 2 Reeve, Eng. Law, 249, 251

title: Family
body: A collective body of .persons who live in one house and under one head or management. Jarboe v. Jarboe, 106 Mo. App. 459, 79 S. W. 1162; Dodge v. Boston A P. It Corp., 154 Mass. 299. 28 N. E. 243, 13 L. R. A. 318; Tyson v. Reynolds, 52 Iowa, 431, 3 N. W. 469

title: Famosus
body: In the clvil and old Engllsh law. i Relating to or affecting character or reputation; defamatory; slanderous

title: Fanal
body: Fr. In French marine law. A large lantern, fixed npon the highest part of a vessel’s stem

title: Fanatics
body: Persons pretending to be Inspired, and being a general name for Quakers, Anabaptists, and all other sectaries, and factious dissenters from the Church of England. (SL 13 Car. U. c. 6.) Jacob

title: Fanega
body: In Spanish law. A measure of land varylng in dlfferent provinces, but in tbe Spanish settlements in America con-slating of 6,400 square varas or yards

title: Fakir
body: ER, or FAKIR. A Hindu term for a poor man, mendicant; a religions beggar

title: Farandman
body: In Scotch law. A traveler or merchant stranger. Skene

title: Fardel Of Land
body: In old English law. The fourth part of a yard-land. Noy says an eighth only, because, according to hlm, two fardels make a nook, and four nooks a yard-land, wharton

title: Fardella
body: In old Eugllsh law. A bundle or pack; a fardel. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 22, $ 10

title: Farding-Deal
body: The fourth part of an acre of land. Spelman

title: Fare
body: RE. A voyage or passage by water; also the money paid for a passage either by land or by water. Cowell

title: Farinagium
body: A mill; a toll of meal or floor. Jacob; Spelman

title: Farleu
body: Money paid by tenants in lieu of a heriot. It was often applied to the best chattel, as dlstlngulshed from heriot, the best beast. Cowell

title: Farlingarh
body: whoremongers and adulterers

title: Farmer
body: 1. The lessee of a farm. It is said that every lessee for life or years, although it be but of a small house and land, is called “farmer.” Thls word implies no mystery, except it be that of husbandman. Cunningham; Cowell

title: Faro
body: An unlawful game of cards, in which all the other players play against the banker or dealer, staking thelr money upon the order in which the cards will lie and be dealt from the pack, webster; ward v. State, 22 Ala. 19; U. S. v. Smith, 27 Fed. Cas. 1149; Patterson v. State, 12 Tex. App. 224

title: Farrago Libelli
body: Lat . An ill-com-posed book containing a collection of mlscel-laneous subjects not properly associated nor scientifically arranged, wharton

title: Farthing
body: The fourth part of an Eng-lish penny

title: Faryndon Inn
body: The ancient appellation of Serjeants’ Inn, Chancery lane

title: Fasius
body: In old English law. A faggot of wood

title: Fast
body: In Georgia, a “fast” bill of excep-tions is one which may be taken in injunc-tion suits and similar cases, at such time and in such manner, as to bring the case up for review with great expedition. It must be certified within twenty days from the render-tag of the decision. Sewell v. Edmonston, 66 Ga. 353

title: Fast-Day
body: A day of fasting and pen-itence, or of mortification by religious absti-nence. See 1 Chit Archh. Pr. (12th Ed.) 160, et seq

title: Fast Estate
body: See Estats

title: Fasting-Men
body: or FASTING-MEN

title: Fasti
body: In Roman law. Lawful. Dies fasti, lawful days; days on which justice could lawfully be administered by the praetor. See Dies Fasti

title: Father
body: The male parent He by whom a child is begotten. As used in law, this term may (according to the context and the nature of the Instrument) include a pu-tatlve as well as a legal father, also a step-father, an adoptive father, or a grandfather, but is not as wide as the word “parent,” and cannot be so construed as to include a female. Lind v. Burke, 56 Neb. 785, 77 N. W. 444; Crook v. webb, 125 Ala. 457, 28 South. 384; Cotheal v. Cotheal, 40 N. Y. 410; Lantznes-ter v. State, 19 Tex. App. 321; Thornburg v. American Strawboard Co., 141 Ind. 443, 40 N. E. 1062, 50 Am. St. Rep. 334

title: Fathom
body: A nautical measure of six feet in length. Occasionally used as a super-ficial measure of land and in mining, and in that case it means a square fathom or thirty-six square feet. Nahaolelua v. Kaaa-hu, 9 Hawaii, 60L

title: Fatua Mulier
body: A whore. Du Fresne

title: Fatuitas
body: In old English law. Fa-tnity; idiocy. Reg. orig. 266

title: Fatum
body: Lat. Fate; a superhuman pow-er; an event or cause of loss, beyond human foresight or means of prevention

title: Fatuous Person
body: one entirely des-tltute of reason; is qui omnino desipit. Ersk. Inst. 1, 7, 48

title: Fatuus
body: An idiot , pr fool. Bract foL 420b

title: Faurourg
body: In French law, and in Louisiana. A district or part of a town ad-joining the principal city; a suburb. See City Couucil of Lafayette v. Holland, 18 La. 286

title: Fauces Terrs
body: (Jaws of the land.) Narrow headlands and promontories, inclos-ing a portion or arm of the sea within them. 1 Kent, Comm. 367, and note; Hale, De Jure Mar. 10; The Harriet, 1 Story, 251, 259, Fed. Cas. No. 6,099

title: Fault
body: In tbe oivil law. Negligence; want of care. An lmproper act or omission, Injurious to another, and transpiring through negligence, rashness, or ignorance

title: Fautor
body: In old English law. A

title: Faux
body: In old English law. False; counterfeit. Faux action, a false actlon. Lltt. | 688. Faux money, counterfeit money. SL westm. 1, c. 15. Faux pegs, false weights. Britt c. 20. Faux serement, a false oath. 8t. westm. 1, c. 38

title: Favor
body: Bias; partiality; lenity; prejudice. See Challenge

title: Feal
body: Faithful. Tenants by knight serv-ice swore to thelr lords to be feal and leal

title: Feal And Divot
body: A right in Scot-land, slmllar to the rlght of turbary in Eng-land, for fuel, etc

title: Fear
body: Apprehension of harm

title: Feasance
body: A doing; the doing of an act See Malfeasance; Misfeasance; Non-feasance

title: Feasant
body: Doing, or making, as, in the term “damage feasant,” (doing damage or Injury,) spoken of cattle straying upon another's land

title: Feasor
body: Doer; maker. Feasors del estaiute, makers of the statute. Dyer, 3b. Also used in the compound term, "tort-feasor," one who commits or is guilty of a tort

title: Feasts
body: Certain established festivals or holidays In the ecclesiastical calendar. These days were anciently uded as the dates of legal Instruments, and in England the quar-ter-days, for paying rent, are four feast-days. The terms of the courts, in England, before 1875, were fixed to begin on certain days determined with reference to the occurrence of four of the chief feasts

title: Fecial Law
body: The nearest approach to a system of International law known to the ancient world. It was a branch of Roman Jurisprudence, concerned with embassies, declarations of war, and treaties of peace. It received this name from the feciales, (q. v.,) who were charged with its administration

title: Feciales
body: Among the ancient Romans, that order of priests who discharged tiie duties of ambassadors. Subsequently their du-tles appear to have related more particular-ly to the declaring war and peace. Calvin

title: Federal
body: In constitutional law. A

title: Fee-Farm
body: This is a species of tenure, where land is held of another in perpetuity at a yearly rent, without fealty, homage, or other services than such as are specially corn-prised in the feoffment It corresponds very nearly to the “emphyteusis” of the Roman law

title: Fee-Simple
body: In English law. A

title: Fee-Tail
body: An estate tail; an estate of inheritance given to a man and the heirs of his body, or limited to certain classes of pnr-tlcular heirs. It corresponds to the feud uni talliatum- Qf the feudal law, aud the Idea is believed to have been borrowed from the Ro-mau law, where, by way of fidei commissa, lands might be entailed upon children and freedmen and their descendants, with restric-tions as to alienation. 1 washb. Real Prop. *66. For the varieties and special characteristics of thia kind of estate, see Tail

title: Feed
body: To lend additional support; to strengthen ex post facto. “The interest when it accrues feeds the estoppel.” Christmas v. oliver, 5 Mood. & R. 202

title: Fegangi
body: In old English law. A thlef caught while escaping with the stolen goods in his possession. Spelman

title: Fehmgerichte
body: The name given to certain secret tribunals which flourished in Germany from the end of the twelfth cen-tury to the middle of the sixteenth, usurping many of the functions of the governments which were too weak to maintain law and order, and inspiring dread in all who came within their jurisdictlon. Enc. Brit. Such a court existed in westphnlia (though wlth greatly diminished powers) until finally sup-pressed in 1811

title: Feigned
body: Fictitious; pretended; sup-posititlous; simulated

title: Felagus
body: In Saxon law. one bound for another by oath; a sworn brother. A friend bound in the decennary for the good behavior of another, one who took the place of the deceased. Thus, if a person was murdered, the recompense due from the murderer went to the fclagus of tlie slain, iu default of parents or lord. Cunniugham

title: Feld
body: A field; in composition, wild. Blount

title: Fele, Feal
body: L. Fr. Faithful. See Feal

title: Fellation
body: See Sodomy

title: Fellow
body: A-companion; one with whom we consort; one joined with another in some legal status or relation; a member of a col-lege or corporate body

title: Fellow-Heir
body: A co-helr; partner of the same Inheritance

title: Fellow-Servants
body: “The decided weight of authority is to the effect that all who serve the same master, work under the same control, derive authority and compen-satlon from tlie same common source, and are engaged in the same general business, though it may be in different grades or departments of it, are fellow-servants, who take the risk of each other’s negligence.” 2 Thomp. Neg. p. 1026, § 31. And see McAndrews v. Burns, 39 N. J- Law, 119; Jnstice v. Pennsylvania Co., 130 Ind. 321, 30 N. E. 303; wright v. New York Cent. R. Co., 25 N. Y. 565; Glover v. Kansas City Bolt Co., 153 Mo. 327, 55 S. W. 88; Brunell v. Southern Pac. Co., 34 or. 256, 56 Pac. 129; Doughty v. Penobscot Log Driving Co., 76 Me. 146; McMaster v. 111-inois Cent. R. Co., 65 Miss. 264, 4 South. 59, 7 Am; St. Rep. 653: Daniels v. Union Pac. Ry. Co.. 6 Utah, 357, 23 Pac. 762; Weeks v. Scharer, 129 Fed. 335, 64 C. C. A, 11

title: Felo De Se
body: A felon of himself; a suicide or murderer of himself, one who deliberately and intentionally puts an end to

title: Felon
body: one who has committed felony; one convicted of felony

title: Felonia
body: Felony. The act or offense by which a vassal forfeited hls fee. Spel-man; Calvln. Per feloniam, with a criminal Intention. Co. Lltt. 391

title: Felonice
body: Feloniously. Anciently an indispensable word in indictments for felony, and classed by Lord Coke among those voces artts (words of art) which cannot be ex-pressed by any periphrasis or circumlocution. 4 Coke, 39; Co. Lltt 391a; 4 Bl. Comm. 307

title: Felonious
body: Malignant; maliciouB; done with lntent to commit a crime; having the grade or quality of a felony. People v. Moore, 37 Hun (N. Y.) 93; Aikman v. Com., 18 S. W. 938, 13 Ky. Law Rep. 894; State v. Bush, 47 Kan. 201, 27 Pac. 834, 13 L. R. A. 607; Com. v. Barlow, 4 Mass. 440

title: Feloniously
body: with a felonious In-tent; with the Intention of committing a crime. An indispensable word in modern indictments for felony, ns fclonicc was in the Latin forms. 4 Bl. Coinm. 307; State v. Jesse. 19 N. C. 300; State v. Smith, 31 wash. 245, 71 Pac. 767; State v. Halpin, 16 S. D. 170, 91 N. W. 605; People v. willett, 102 N. Y. 251, 6 N. E. 301; State v. watson, 41 La. Ann. 598, 7 South. 125; State v. Bryan, 112 N. C. 848, 16 S. E. 909

title: Felony
body: In English law. Thjs term meant originally the state of having forfeited lands and goods to the crown upon convic-tion for certain offenses, and then, by transi-tion, any offense upon conviction for which such forfeiture followed, in addition to any other punishment prescribed hy law; as dis

title: Female
body: The sex which conceives and gives birth to young. Also a member of snch sex. The term is generic, but may have the specific meaning of “woman,” if so in-dlcated by the context. State v. Hemm, 82 Iowa, 609, 48 N. W. 971

title: Feme
body: L. Fr. A woman. In the phrase “baron et feme" (q. v.) the word has the sense of “wife.”

title: Femicide
body: The killing of a woman. Wharton

title: Fenatio
body: In forest law. The fawn-lng of deer; the fawning season. Spelman

title: Feneration
body: Usury; the gain of in-terest; the practice of increasing money by lending

title: Fengeld
body: In Saxon law. A tax or imposition, exacted for the repelling of en-emies

title: Fenian
body: A champion, hero, giant This word, in the plural, is generally used to signify invaders or foreign spoilers. The modern meaning of “fenian” is a member of an organization of persons of Irish birth, resident in the United States, Canada, and elsewhere, having for its aim the overthrow of English rule in Ireland, webster, (Supp

title: Feod
body: The same as feud or fief

title: Feodal
body: Belonging to a fpe or feud; feudal. More commonly used by the old writers than feudal

title: Feodal System
body: See Feudal Srs-TEM

title: Feodality
body: Fidelity or fealty. Cow-ell. See Fealty

title: Feodarum Consuetudines
body: The

title: Feodary
body: An oflicer of the court of wards, appointed by the master of that court, under 32 Hen. VIII. c. 20, whose business if was to be present with the escheator in every county at the finding of offices of lands, and to give evidence for the king, as well concerning the value as the tenure; and hia office was also to survey the land of the ward, after the office found, and to rate it. He also assigned the king’s widows their dower; and received all the rents, etc. Abol-lshed by 12 Car. II. c. 24. wharton

title: Feodatory
body: In feudal law. The grantee of a feod, feud, or fee; the vassal or tenant who held his estate by feudal service. Termes de la Ley. Blackstone uses “feudatory." 2 Bl. Comm. 46

title: Feodi Firma
body: In old English law. Fee-farm, (q. v

title: Feodi Firmarius
body: The lessee of a fee-farm

title: Feodum
body: This word (meaning a feud or fee) is the one most commonly used by the older English law-writers, though its equlva-lent, “feud urn,” is used generally by the more modern writers nnd by the feudal law-writers. Litt. 8 1; Spelman. There were various classes of feoda, among which may be enumerated the following; Feodum latent m, a lay fee. Feodum militare, a knight's fee. Feodum improprium, an improper or derivative fee. Feodum proprium, a proper and original fee, regulated by the strict rules of feudal succession and tenure. Feodum simplex, a simple or pure fee; fee-simple. Feodum talliatum, a fee-tail. See 2 Bl. Comm. 58, 62; Litt SS 1. 13; Bract fol. 175; Gian. 13, 23

title: Feoffamentum
body: A feoffment. 2 BL Comm. 310

title: Feoffare
body: To enfeoff; to bestow a fee. The bestower was called “fcoffator,” and the grantee or feoffee, “feoffat us

title: Feoffator
body: In old English law. A feoffer; one who gives or bestows a fee; one who makes a feoffment Bract fols. 12b, 81

title: Feoffatus
body: In old Engllsh law. A feoffee; one to whom a fee is given, or a feoffment made. Bract fols. 17b, 44b

title: Feoffee
body: He to whom a fee is conveyed. Litt § 1; 2 Bl. Comm. 20

title: Feoffment
body: The gift of any corpo-real hereditament to another, (2 Bl. Comm. 310), operating by transmutation of possession, and requiring, as essential to its com-pletlon, that the selsen be passed, (watk. Conv. 183), whlch might he accomplished elther by investiture or by livery of seisin

title: Feoffor
body: The person making a feoff-ment, or enfeoffing another in fee. 2 BL Comm. 310; Litt. H 1, 57

title: Feoh
body: This Saxon word meant originally cattle, and thence property or money, and, by a second transition, wages, reward, or , fee. It was probably the original form from which the words “feod,” “feudum,” “fief,” “feu,” and “fee” (all meaning a feudal grant of land) have been derived

title: Feonatio
body: In forest law. The fawning season of deer

title: Feorme
body: A certain portion of the prod-uce of the land dne by the grantee to the lord according to the terms of the charter. Spel. Feuds, c. 7

title: Fercosta
body: Ital. A kind of small ves-sel or boat. Mentioned in old Scotch law, and called “fercost” Skene

title: Ferdella Terrze
body: A fardel-land; ten acres; or perhaps a yard-land. Cowell

title: Ferdfare
body: Sax. A summons to serve-in the army. An acquittance from going into-the army. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 47, ( 23

title: Ferdingus
body: A term denoting, appar-ently, a freeman of the lowest class, being named after the cotseti

title: Ferdwite
body: In Saxon law. An acquittance of manslaughter committed in tbe army; also a fine imposed on persons for net going forth on a military expedition. Cow-ell

title: Feria
body: In old English law. A weekday ; a holiday; a day on which process could not be served; a fair; a ferry. Cowell; Du Cange; Spelman

title: Ferial Days
body: Holiday*; also weekdays, as distinguished from Sunday. Cowell

title: Ferita
body: In old European law. A wound; a stroke. Spelman

title: Ferling
body: In old records. The fourth part of a penny; also the quarter of a ward in a borongh

title: Ferling At A
body: A fourth part of a yard-land

title: Ferlxngus
body: A furlong. Co. Litt 5b

title: Fearm
body: or FEARM. A house or land, or both, let by lease. Cowell

title: Ferme
body: A farm; a rent; a lease; a house or land, or both, taken by indenture or lease. Plowd. 195; Vicat, See Fabm

title: Fermented Liquors
body: Beverages produced by, or whlch have undergone, a process of alcohollc fermentation, to which they owe their intoxicating properties, including beer, wine, hard cider, and the like, but uot spirituous or distilled, liquors. State v. Lemp, IQ Mo. 391; State v. Biddle, 54 N. H. 383; People v. Foster, 64 Mich. 715, 31 N. W. 596; State v. Gill, 89 Minn. 502, 95 N, W. 449; State v. Adams, 51 N. H. 568

title: Fermer, Fermor
body: A lessee; a farmer. one who holds a term, whether of lauds or an lucorporeal right, such as customs or revenue

title: Fermier
body: In French law. one who farms any public revenue

title: Fermisona
body: In old English law. The wlnter season for kllling deer

title: Fermory
body: In old records. A place in monasteries, where they recelved the poor, (Aospieio cxcipiebant,) and gave them pro-visions, (ferm, firma.) Spelman. Hence the modern infirmary, used in the sense of a hospital

title: Fernigo
body: In old English law. A waste ground, or place where fern grows. Cowell

title: Ferri
body: In the eivll law. To be borne; that is on or about the per> This was dis-tinguished from portari, (to . , carried,) which signified to be carried on an animal. Dig. 50, 16, 235

title: Ferriage
body: The toll or fare paid for the transportation of persons and property across a ferry

title: Ferrifodina
body: In old pleading. An iron mlne. Townsh. Pl. 273

title: Ferrum
body: Iron. In old English law. A,horse-shoe. Ferrara, shoeing of horses

title: Ferry
body: A liberty to have a boat upon a river for the transportation of men, horses, and carriages with thelr contents, for a ren-sonable toll. The term is also used to desig-nate the (place where such liberty is exer-cised. See New York v. Starin, 8 N. Y. St. Rep. 655; Broaduax v. Baker, 94 N. C. 681, 55 Am, Itep. 633 ; Elnstman v. Black, 14 111

title: Festa In Cappis
body: In old English law. Grand holidays, on which choirs wore caps. Jacob

title: Festing-Man
body: In old English law. A frank-pledge, or one who was surety for the good behavior of another. Monasteries enjoyed the privilege of belng “free from festlng-men," whlch means that they wer» “not bound for any man’s forthcoming who should transgress the law.” Cowell. See Fbank-Pledqe

title: Festing-Penny
body: Earnest given to servants when hired or retained. The same as arles-penny. Cowell

title: Festinum Remedium
body: Lat A

title: Festum
body: A feast or festival. Festum stultorum, the feast of fools

title: Fetters
body: Chains or shackles for the feet; irons used to secure the legs of convicts, unruly prisoners, etc. Simllar chains securing the wrists are called “handcuffs.”

title: Feu Et Lieu
body: Fr. In old French and Canadian law. Hearth and home. A term importing actual settlement upon laud by a tenant

title: Feud
body: In feudal law. An estate in land held of a superior on condition of ren-derlng him services. 2 Bl. Comm* 105

title: Feuda
body: Feuds or fees

title: Feudal
body: Pertaining to fends or fees; relating to or growing out of the feudal sys-tem or feudal law; haying the quality of a feud, as distinguished from “allodial.”

title: Feudalism
body: The feudal system; the aggregate of feudal principles and usages

title: Feudalize
body: To reduce to a feudal ten-ure; to conform to feudalism, webster

title: Feudary
body: A tenant who holds hy feu* dal tenure, (also spelled “feodatory" and “feudatory.") Held by feudal service. Re-lating to feuds or feudal tenures

title: Feudbote
body: A recompense for engaging in a feud, and the damages consequent, it having been the custom in ancicnt times for all the kindred to engage in their kinsman’s quarrel. Jacob

title: Feude
body: An occasional early form of “feud” in the sense of private war or ven-geance. Termes de la Ley. See Feud

title: Feudist
body: A writer on feuds, as Cuja-cius, Spelman, etc

title: Feudo
body: In Spanish law. Feud or fee. white, New Recop. b. 2, tit. 2, c. 2

title: Feudum
body: L. Lat. A feud, fief, or fee. A right of using nnd enjoying forever the lands of another, whieh tlie lord grants on condition that the tenant shall render fealty, mllitary duty, and other services. Spelman

title: Fi. Fa
body: An abbreviation for fieri facias, (which see

title: Fiancer
body: L. Fr. To pledge one’s faith. Kelham

title: Fianza
body: Sp. in Spanish law, trust, con-fldence, and correlatively a legal duty or ob-ligatiou arising therefrom. The term is suffl-clentiy broad lu meanlng to include both a general obligation and a restricted liability under a single Instrument Martinez v. Run-kle. 57 N. J. Law, 111, 30 Atl. 593. But in a special sense, it designates a surety or guarantor, or the contract or engagement of suretyship

title: Fiar
body: lu Scotch law. He that has the fee or feu. The proprietor is termed “fiar,” In contradistinction to the life-renter. 1 Kames, Eq. Pref. one whose projierty is charged with a life-rent

title: Fiars Prices
body: The value of grain in the different counties of Scotland, fixed year

title: Fiat
body: (Lat. “Let it be done.”) In Eng-llsh practice. A short order or warrant of a judge or magistrate directing some act to be done; an authority issuing from some competent source for the dolng of some legal act

title: Figtio
body: In Roman law. A fiction; an assumption or supposition of the law

title: Fiotion
body: An assumptlon or supposition of law that something which is or may be false is true, or that a state of facts exists

title: Fictitious
body: Founded on a fiction; having the character of a flctlon; false, feigned, or pretended

title: Fide-Commissary
body: A term derived from the Latin “fldci-commissartus," and oc-casionally used by writers on equity juris-prudence as a substitute for the law French term "cestui que trust," as being more ele-gant and euphonious. See Brown v. Brown, 83 Hun, 160, 31 N. Y. Supp. 650

title: Fidei-Commissarius
body: In the civil law thls term corresponds nearly to our “cestui que trust." It designates a person who has the real or beneficlal Interest in an estate or fund, the title or administration of which is temporarily confided to another. See Story, Eq. Jur. | 966

title: Fidei-Commissum
body: In the civil law. A species of trust; being a gift of property

title: Fide-Jubere
body: In the clvil law. To order a thing upon one’s faith; to pledge one’s self; to become surety for another. Fide-jubes? Fide-jubeo: Do you pledge your-self? I do pledge myself. Inst 3, 16, 1. one of the forms of stipulation

title: Fide-Jussor
body: In Roman law. A guarantor; one who becomes responsible for the payment of another’s debt, by a stipulation which binds him to dlscharge it if the prin-cipal debtor fails to do so. Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 452 ; 3 Bl. Comm. 108

title: Fide-Promissor
body: See Fide-Jussor

title: Fidelitas
body: Lat Fealty, (q. v

title: Fidelity Insurance
body: See Insvb-ANCE

title: Fidem Mentiri
body: Lat To betray faith or fealty. A term used in feudal and old English law of a feudatory or feudal tenant who does not keeP that fealty which he bas sworn to the lord. Leg. Hen. I. c. 53

title: Fides
body: Lat Faith; honesty; confidence; trust; veracity; honor, occurring in the phrases “bona fldes," (good faith,) “mala fldes," (bad faith,) and “uberrima fldes," (the utmost or most abundant good faith

title: Fiducial
body: An adjective having the same meaning as “fiduciary;’’ as, in the phrase “public or fiducial ofiice.” Ky. St. § 3752; Moss v. Rowlett, 112 Ky. 121, 65 S. W. 153

title: Fiduciarius Tutor
body: In Roman law. The elder brother of an emancipated pupil-lus, whose father had died leaving him still under fourteen years of age

title: Fiduciary
body: The term is derived from the Roman law, and means (as a noun) a person holding the character of a trustee, or a character analogous to that of a trustee, in respect to the trust and confidence involved in it and the scrupulous good faith and can-dor which it requires. Thus, a person ij a fiduciary who is Invested with rights and powers to be exercised for the benefit of another person. Svanoe v. Jurgens, 144 111. 507, 33 N. E. 955; Stoll v. King, 8 How. Prnc. (N. ¥.) 299

title: Fief
body: A fee, feod, or feud

title: Fief-Tenant
body: In old English law.* The holder of a fief or fee; a feeholder on l reeholder

title: Fiel
body: In Spanish lnw. A sequestrator; a persou in whose hands a thlng in dispute is judicially deposited; a receiver. Las Par-* tidas, pt. 3, tit. 9, 1. 1

title: Field
body: This term might well be con-; sidered as definite and certain a description as “close,” and might be used in law; but it is not a usual description in legal proceedings. 1 Chit Gen. Pr. 160

title: Field-Ale
body: An ancient custom in Eng-land, by which officers of the forest and bailiffs of hundreds had the right to compel the hundred to furnish them with ale. Tom-lins

title: Field Reeve
body: An officer elected, in England, by the owners of a regulated pas-‘ ture to keep in order the fences, ditches, etc.,’ on the land, to regulate the times during which animals are to be admitted to the pasture, and generally to maintain nnd man-age the pasture subject to the instructions of the owners. (General Iudosure Act, 1845, | 118.) Sweet

title: Fieldad
body: In Spanish law. Sequestra-, tion. This is allowed in six cases by tlie Spanish law w’here the title to property is' in dispute. Las Partidas, pt 3, tit 3, 1. 1

title: Fierding Courts
body: Ancient Gothic courts of an inferior jurisdiction, so called

title: Fieri
body: Lat To be made; to be done. See In Fieri

title: Fieri Facias
body: (That you cause.to be made.) in practice. A writ of execution commanding the sheriff to levy and make the amount of a Judgment from the goods and chattels of the judgment debtor

title: Fieri Feci
body: (I have caused to he made.) In practice. The name given to the return made by a sheriff or other officer to a writ of fieri facias, where he has collected the whole, or a part, of the sum directed to be levied. 2 Tidd, Pr. 1018. The return, os actually made, is expressed by the word “Satisfied” indorsed on the writ

title: Fifteenths
body: In English law. This was originally a tax or tribute, levied at ln-tervals by act of parliament, consisting of one-fifteenth of all the movable property of the subject or personalty in every city, town-ship, nnd borough. Under Edward III., the taxable property was assessed, and the value of its fifteenth part (then about £29,000) was recorded in the exchequer, whence the tax, levied dn that valuation, continued to be called a “fifteenth,” although, as the wealth of the kingdom increased, the name ceased to be an accurate designation of the propor-tion of the tax to the value taxed. See 1 Bl. Comm. 309

title: Fight
body: An encounter, with blows or other personal violence, between two persons. See State v. Gladden, 73 N. C. 155; Carpen-ter v. People, 31 Colo. 284, 72 Pac. 1072; Coles v. New York Casualty Co., 87 App. Dlv. 41, 83 N.. Y. Supp. 1063

title: Filacer
body: An officer of the superior courts at westminster, whose duty it was to file the writs on Which he made process. There were fourteen filacers, and it was their duty to make out all orlglual process. Cow-ell; Blount. The office was abolished in 1837

title: Filare
body: In old Engllsh practice. To file. Townsh. Pl. 67

title: Fileinjaid
body: Brit. A name given to villeins in the laws of Hoel Ddn. Barring, obs. St 302

title: Filiate
body: To fix a bastard child on some one, as Its father. To declare whose child it is. 2 W. Bl. 1017

title: Filiation
body: The relation of a child to its parent; correlative to “paternity.”

title: Filicetum
body: In old English law. A ferny or bracky ground: a place where fern grows. Co. Litt. 4b; Shep. Touch. 95

title: Filiolus
body: In old records. A godson. Spelman

title: Filius
body: Lat A son; a child

title: Fill
body: To make full; to complete; to sat-isfy or fulfill; to possess and perform the duties of

title: Filly
body: A young mare; a female colt An indictment charging the theft of a “filly" is not sustained by proof oi the larceny of a “mare.” Lunsford v. State, J Tex. App. 448, 28 Am. Rep. 414

title: Filum
body: Lat in old practice. A file; i. e., a thread or wire on which papers were strung, that being the ancient method \>f filing

title: Fin De Non Recevoir
body: In French law. An exception or plea founded on law, which, without entering lnto the merits of the actlon, shows that the piaintiiE has no rigbt to bring it, either because the time dur-lng which it ought to have been brought has elapsed, which is called “prescription,” or that there has been a compromise, accord and satisfaction, or any other cause which has destroyed the right of action which once subsisted. Poth. Proc. Civile, pt 1, c. 2, $ 2, art. 2

title: Final
body: Definitive; terminating; completed ; last. In its use in jurisprudence, this word is generally contrasted with “interlocu-tory.” Johnson v. New York, 48 Hun, 620, 1 N. Y. Supp. 254; Garrison v. Dpugherty, 18 S. C. 488; Rondeau v. Beaumette, '4 Minn. 224 (Gil. 163); Blanding v. Sayles, 23 R. I. 226, 49 AU 992

title: Finalis Concordia
body: A final or con-clusive agreement. In the process of “levying a fine,” this was a final agreement entered by the litigating parties upon the record, hy permission of court, nettling the title to the land, and which was binding upon them like any judgment of the court. 1 washb. Real Prop. *70

title: Finances
body: The public wealth of a state or government, considered either statically

title: Financier
body: A person employed in the economical management and application of public money; one skilled in the manage-ment of financial affairs

title: Find
body: To discover; to determine; to as-certaln and declare. To announce a conclu-sion, as the result of judlcial investigation, u]>on a dlsputed fact or state of facts; as a Jury are sald to “find a wlll.” To determine a controversy in favor of one of the parties; as a jury “find for the plaintiff.” State v. Buikeley, 61 Conn. 287, 23 Atl. 186, 14 L. R

title: Finder
body: Dne who discovers and takes possession of another’s personal property, which wns then lost. Kincaid v. Eaton, 98 Mass. 139, 93 Am. Dec. 142

title: Finding
body: A decision npon a question of fact reached as the result of a judicial ex-amlnation or Investigation by a court, jury, referee, coroner, etc. williams v. Giblin, 86 wis. 648, 57 N. W. 1111; Rhodes v. United 8tates Bank, 66 Fed. 514,13 C. 0. A. 612, 34 L. R. A. 742

title: Fine Anullando Levato De Tenemento Quod Fuit De Antiq-Uo Domuyico
body: Ad abolished writ for dis-annulling a fine levied of lands in ancient demesne to the prejudice of the lord. Reg. orig. 15

title: Fine Capiendo Pro Terris
body: An

title: Fine Non Capiendo Pro Pul-Chre Placitando
body: An obsolete writ to inhibit officers of courts to take fines for fair pleading

title: Fine-Force
body: An absolute necessity or inevitable constraint. Plowd. 94; 6 Coke, 11; Cowell

title: Finem Facere
body: To make or pay a flne. Bract. 106

title: Fines Le Roy
body: In old English lnw. The king’s fines. Fines formerly payable to the king for any contempt or offense, as where one committed any trespass, or false-ly denied his own deed, or did anything in contempt of law. Termes de la Ley

title: Finire
body: In old Engllsh lnw. To flne, or pay a flne. Cowell. To end or fluish a matter

title: Finis
body: Lat. An end; a fine; a boundary or terminus; a limit Also in L. Lat., a fine (q. v

title: Finitio
body: An endlng; death, as the end of llfe. Blount; Cowell

title: Finium Regundorum Actio
body: In

title: Finors
body: Those that purify gold and silver, and part them by fire and water from coarser metals; and therefore, in the statute of 4 Hen. VII. c. 2, they are also called “parters.” Termes de la Ley

title: Firdfare
body: Sax. In old Engllsh law. A summoning forth to a military expedition, (indictio ad profectionem militarem.) Spel-mau

title: Firdiringa
body: Sax. A preparation to go lnto the army. Leg. Hen. I

title: Firdsocne
body: Sax. In old English law. Exemption from military service. Spelman

title: Firdwite
body: In old English law. A fine for refusing military servlce, (mnlcta Aetrec-tantis militiam.) Spelman

title: Fire
body: The efTect of combustion. The juridical meaning of the word does not differ from the vernacular. 1 Pars. Mar. Law, 231, et seq

title: Firlot
body: A Scotch measure of capacity, containing two gallons aud a pint. Spelman

title: Firm
body: A partnership; the group of per-sons constituting a partnership. The name or title under which the members of a partnership transact business.—People v. Strauss, 97 111. App. 55; Boyd v. Thompson, 153 Pa. 82, 25 Atl. 769, 34 Am. St. Rep. 685; Mc-Cosker v. Banks, 84 Md. 292, 35 Atl. 935

title: Firma
body: In old Engllsh law. The con-tract of lease or letting; also the rent (or farm) reserved upon a lease of lands, which was frequently payable in provisions, but sometimes in money, in which latter case it was called “alba firma," white rent. A mes-saage, with the house and garden belonging thereto. Also provision for the table; a banquet; a tribute towards the entertainment of the king for one night

title: Firman
body: A Turkish word denoting a decree or grant of privileges, or passport to a traveler

title: Firmaratio
body: The right of a tenant to hls lands and tenements. Cowell

title: Firmarium
body: In old records. A place in monasteries, and elsewhere, where the poor were received and supplied with food. Spelman. Hence the word, “infirmary.”

title: Firmarius
body: L. Lat. A fermor. A lessee of a term. Firmarii comprehend all such as hold by lease for life or lives or for year, by deed or without deed. 2 Iust. 144, 145; 1 washb. Real Prop. 107

title: Fukmatio
body: The doe season. Also a supplylng with food. Cowell

title: Firmitas
body: In oid Eugllsh law. Au as* surance of some privilege, by deed or char-ter

title: Firmly
body: A statement tliut an affiant “firmly believes” the contents of the attida-vit Imports a strong or high degree of belief, and is equivalent to saying that he “verily” believes it. Bradley v. Eccles, 1 Browne (Pa.) 258; Thompson v. white, 4 Serg. & R. (Pa.) 137. The operative words in a bond or recognizance, that the obligor is held and “firmly bound,” are equivalent to an acknowledgment of indebtedness and promise to pay. Shattuck v. People, 5 111 477

title: Firmura
body: In old English law. Liberty to scour and repair a mill-dam, aud carry away the soil, etc. Blount

title: First
body: Inltial; leading; chief; preceding all others of the same kind or class in sequence, (numerical or chronological;) en-tltled to priority or preference above others. Redman v. Railroad Co., 33 N. J. Eq. 165; Thompson v. Grand Gulf R. & B. Co., 3 How. (Miss.) 247, 34 Am. Dec. 81; Hapgood v. Brown, 102 Mass. 452

title: Fisc
body: An Anglicized form of the Latin "flseus," (whlch see

title: Fiscal
body: Belonglng to the fisc, or pub-llc treasury. Relating to accounts or the management of revenue

title: Fiscus
body: In Roman la*. The treasury of the prince or emperor, as distinguished from “ararium " which was the treasury of the state. Spelman

title: Fish
body: An animal which inhabits the wa-ter, breathes by means of gills, swims by the aid of fins, and is oviparous

title: Fishery
body: A place prepared for catch-ing fish with nets or hooks. This is com-monly applied to the place of drawing a seine or net Hart v. Hill, 1 whart. (Pa.) 131, 132

title: Fishgarth
body: A dam or wear in a river for taking fish. Cowell

title: Fishing Bill
body: A term descriptive of a blll in equity which seeks a discovery up-on general, loose, and vague allegations. Story, Eq. Pl. 4 325; In re Pacific Ry. Com’n (C. C.) 32 Fed. 263; Hurricane Tel. Co. ▼. Mohler, 61 W. Va. 1, 41 S. E. 421; Carroll v. Carroll, 11 Barb. (N. Y.) 298

title: Fisk
body: In Scotch law. The flscus or fisc. The revenue of the crown. Generally used of the personal estate of a rebel which has been forfeited to the crown. Bell

title: Fissure Vein
body: In mining law. A vein or lode of mineralized matter filling a pre-existing fissure or crack In the earth's crust extending across the strata and gen

title: Festuoa
body: or FESTUOA. In old English law. Tbe rod or wand, by the dellvery of whlch the property in land was formerly transferred in making a feoffment. Called, also, "baculum," “virga," and “fustis." Spel-man

title: Fistula
body: In the clvll law. A pipe for conveying water. Dig. 8, 2, 18

title: Fitz
body: A Norman word, meaning “son.** It is used in law and genealogy; as Fitsher-bert, the son of Herbert; Fitzjames, the son of James; Fitzroy, the son of the king. It was originally applied to illegitimate chil-dren

title: Ftve-Mile Act
body: An act of parliament, passed in 1065, against non-conform-ists, whereby ministers of that body were prohibited from coming withln five miles of any corporate town, or place where they had preached or lectured. Brown

title: Fixture
body: 1. A fixture is a personal chattel substantially affixed to the land, hut which may afterwards be lawfully removed therefrom by the party affixing it, or his representative, without the consent of the owner of the freehold. Cook’v. whiting, 16 111 480; Teaff v. Hewitt, 1 Qhio St. 511, 59

title: Flaoo
body: A place covered with standing water

title: Flag
body: A national standard on which are certain emblems; an ensign; a banuer. It is carried by soldiers, ships, etc., and com-monly displayed at forts and many other suitable places

title: Flagellat
body: whipped; scourged. An entry on old Scotch records. 1 Pitc. Crim. Tr. pt. 1, p. 7

title: Flagrans
body: Lat Burning; raging; in actual perpetration

title: Flagrant Delit
body: In French law. A crime which is in actual process of perpetration or which has just been committed. Oode d’Instr. Crim. art. 41

title: Flagrant Necessity
body: A case of urgency rendering lawful an otherwise illegal act, as an assault to remove a man from impending danger

title: Flash Check
body: A check drawn upon a hanker by a person who has no funds at the banker’s and knows that such is the case

title: Flat
body: A place covered with water too shallow for navigation with vessels ordinarily used for commercial purposes. The space between high and low water mark along the edge of an arm of the sea, bay, tidal river, etc. Thomas v. Hatch, 23 Fed. Cas. 946; Church v. Meeker, 34 Conn. 424; Jones v. Janney, 8 watts & S. (Pa.) 443, 42 Am. Dec. 309

title: Flavianvm Jus
body: In Roman law. The title of a book containing the forms of actions, published by Cneius Flavius, A. U. C. 449. Mackeld. Rom. Law, { 39. Calvln

title: Flecta
body: A’ feathered or fleet arrow. CoweU

title: Fledwite
body: A discharge or freedom from amercements where one, havlng been an outlawed fugitive, cometh to the place of our lord of his own accord. Termes de ia Ley

title: Flee From Justice
body: To leave one’s home, residence, or known place of abode, or to conceal one’s self therein, wlth intent, in either case, to avoid detection or punishment for some public offense. Streep v. U

title: Flee To The Wall
body: A metaphorical expression, used in connection with hornl-clde done In self-defense, signifying the exhaustion of every possible means of escape, or of averting the assault, before killing the assailant

title: Fleet
body: A place where the tide flows; a creek, or Inlet of water; a company of ships or navy ; a prison in London, (so called from a river or ditch formerly in its vicinity,) now abolished by 5 & 6 Vict. c. 22

title: Flem
body: In Saxon and old Engllsh law

title: Flymena Frynthe
body: LEMENES FRINTHE—FLYMENA FRYNTHE. The

title: Flemeswite
body: The possession of the goods of fugitives. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 147

title: Flet
body: In Saxon law. Land; a house; home

title: Flichwite
body: In Saxon law. A fine on account of 'brawls aud quarrels. Spelman

title: Flight
body: In criminal law. The act of one under accusation, who evades the law by voluntarily withdrawing hlmself. It is presumptive evidence of guilt U. S. v. Candler (D. C.) 65 Fed. 312

title: Float
body: In American land law, espe-dally in the western states. A certificate authorizing the entry, by the holder, of a certain quantity of lnnd not yet specifically selected or located. U. S. ▼. Central Pac

title: Floatable
body: Used for floating. A floatable stream is a stream used for floating logs, rafts, etc. Gerrish v. Brown, 51 Me. 260, 81 Am. Dec. 569; Gaston v. Mace, 33 W. Va. 14, 10 S. E. 60, 5 L. R. A. 392, 25 Am. St. Rep. 848; Parker v. Hastings, 123 N. CL 671, 31 S. E. 833

title: Floating Debt
body: By this term is meant that mass of lawful and valid claims against the corporation for the payment of which there is no money in the corporate treasury specifically designed, nor any taxa-tion nor other means of providing money to pay particularly provided. People v. wood. 71 N. Y. 374: City of Huron v. Second ward Sav. Bank. 86 Fed. 276, 30 C. C. A. 38, 49 L. R. A. 534

title: Flode-Mark
body: Flood-mark, high-wa-*er mark. The mark which the sea, at flow-ing water .and highest tide, makes on the shore. Blount

title: Floor
body: A section of a building between horizontal planes. Lowell v. Strahan, 145 Mass. 1, 12 N. E. 401. 1 Am. St. Rep. 422

title: Florentine Pandects
body: A copy of the Pandects discovered .accidentally about the year 1137, at Amalphl, a town in Italy, near Salerno. From Amalphl, the copy fonnd its way to Pisa, and, Pisa having sub-mltted to the Florentines in 1406, the copy was removed in great triumph to Florence. By direction of the magistrates of the town, it was immediately bound in a superb man-ner, and deposited in a costly chest. For-merly, these Pandects were shown only by torch-light, in the presence of two magis-trates, and two Cistercian monks, with their heads uncovered. They have been succes-sively collated b.v Politian, Bolognini, and Antonlus Augustinus. An exact copy of them was published in'1553 by Franciscus Taurellus. For its accuracy and beauty, this edition ranks high among the ornaments of the press. Brenchman, who collated the manuscript about 1710, refers it to the sixth century. Butl. Hor. Jur. 90, 91

title: Florin
body: A coin originally made at Florence, now of the value of about two English shillings

title: Flotages
body: 1. Such things as by accl-dent swim on the top of great rivers or the sea. Cowell

title: Flotsam, Flotsan
body: A name for the goods which float upon the sea when cast overboard for the safety of the ship, or when a ship is sunk. Distinguished from “jet-sam” and “ligan.” Bract, llb. 2, c. 5; 5 Coke, 106; 1 Bl. Comm. 292

title: Floud-Marke
body: In oid English law. High-water mark; flood-mark. 1 And. 88.89

title: Flowing Lands
body: This term has ac-quired a definite and specific meaning in latv. It commonly imports raising and set-ting back water on another’s land, by a dam placed across a stream or water-course which is the natural drain and outlet for surplus water on such land. Call v. Middle-sex County Com’rs, 2 Gray (Mass.) 235

title: Fluctus
body: Flood; flood-tide. Bract, fol

title: Flumen
body: In Roman law. A servi* tude which conslsts in the right to conduct the rain-water, collected from the roof and carried off by the gutters, onto the house or

title: Fluminab Vqlucres
body: wild fowl; water-fowl. 11 East, 571, note

title: Fluvtus
body: Lat. A river; a public river; flood ; flood-tide

title: Fluxus
body: In old English law. Flow. Per fluxum et refluxum maris, by the flow and reflow of the sea. Dal. pl. 10

title: Fly For It
body: on a criminal trial in former times, it was usual after a verdict of not guilty to inquire also, “Did he fly for it?” This practice was abolished by the 7 ft 8 Geo. IV., c. 28, t 5. wharton

title: Flying Switch
body: In railroading, a flying switch is made by uncoupling the cars from the engine while in motion, and throw-ing the cars onto the side track, by turning the switch, after the engine has passed it upon the main track. Greenleaf v. Illinois Cent. R. Co., 29 Iowa, 39, 4 Am. Rep. 181; Baker v. Railroad Co., 122 Mo. 533, 26 S. W. 20

title: Flyma
body: In old English law. A run-away; fugltive; one escaped from justice, or who has no “hlaford

title: Flyman.Frymth
body: In oid English law. The offense of harboring a fugitive, the penalty attached to which was one of the rights of the crown

title: Focage
body: House-bote; fire-bote. Cowell

title: Focale
body: In old Engllsh law. Firewood. The rlght of taking wood for the fire. Fire-bote. Cunningham

title: Fodder
body: Food for horses or cattle. In 'eudal law, the term also denoted a preroga-tive of the prince to be provided with corn, etc., for his horses by his subjects in his wars

title: Fodertorium
body: Provisions to be paid by custom to the royal purveyors. Cowell

title: Foderum
body: See Foddeb

title: Fodina
body: A mine. Co. Lltt 6a

title: Fcedus
body: In international law. A treaty; a league; a compact

title: Fcenus
body: Lat in the clvll law. Interest on money; the lending of money on lnterest

title: Fcbtioide
body: In medical jurisprudence. Destruction of the ftetus; the act by which criminal abortion is produced. 1 Beck, Med. Jur. 288; Guy, Med. Jur. 133

title: Fcetura
body: In the civil law. The pro-duce of animals, and the fruit of other prop-erty, which are acquired to the owner of such animals and property by virtue of his right. Btfwyer, Mod. Clvil Law, c. 14, p. 81

title: Fcetus
body: In medical jurisprudence. An unborn child. An infant in ventre sa m&re

title: Fogagium
body: In old Engllsh law. Fog-gage or fog; a kind of rank grass of late growth, and not eaten in summer. Spelman; Cowell

title: Foinesun
body: In old English law. The fawnlng of deer. Spelman

title: Fcemina Vtro Co-Operta
body: A mar- FOIRFAULT. In old Scotch law. To ried woman; a feme covert. forfeit 1 How. State Tr. 027

title: Foirthooht
body: In old Scotch law. Forethought; premeditated. 1 Pltc. Crim. Tr. pt 1, p. 90

title: Foiterers
body: Vagabonds. Blount

title: Folc-Gemote
body: In Saxon law. A general assembly of the people in a town or ahire. It appears to have had judiclal func-tions of a limited nature, and also to have discharged political offices, such as deliberat-lng upon the affairs of the commonwealth or complaining of misgovernment, and probably possessed considerable powers of local self-government. The name was also given to any sort of a popular assembly. See Spelman; Manwood; Cunningham

title: Folc-Land
body: In Saxon law.. Land of the folk or people. Land belonging to the people or the public

title: Folc-Mote
body: A general assembly of the people, under the Saxons. See Folo-Gbmotb

title: Folc-Right
body: The common right of all the people. 1 Bl. Comm. 65, 67

title: Fold-Course
body: In English law. Land to which the sole right of folding the cattle of others is appurtenant. Sometimes it means merely such right of folding. Tbe right of folding on another’s land, which is called “common foldage.” Co. Lltt. 6a, note 1

title: Foldage
body: A privilege possessed in some placee by the lord of a manor, which con-sists in the rigbt of having his tenant’s sheep to feed on his fields, so as to manure the land. The name of foldage is also given in parts of Norfolk to the customary fee paid to the lord for exemption at certain times from this duty. Elton, Com. 45, 46

title: Folgarh
body: Menial servants; followers. Bract

title: Folgere
body: In old Engllsh law. A freeman, who has no house or dwelling of hls own, but is the follower or retalner of an-other, (heorthfoeat.) for whom he performs certain predial services

title: Folio
body: 1. A leaf. In the ancient law-books it was the custom to number the leaves, instead of the pages; hence a folio would in-dude both sides of the leaf, or two pages. The references to these books are made by the number of the folio, the letters “a” and “b” being added to show which of the two pages is intended; thus “Bracton, fol. 100a.”

title: Folk-Land; Folk-Mote
body: See

title: Follow
body: To conform to, comply with, or be fixed or determined by; as in the ex-presslons “costs follow the event of the suit,” “the situs of personal property follows that of the owner,” “the offspring follows the mother,” (partus sequitur ventrem

title: Fonds Et Biens
body: Fr. In French law. Goods and effects. Adams v. Akerlund, 168 111. 632, 48 N. E. 454

title: Fonds Perdus
body: In French law. A capital is said to be invested d fond* perdus when it is stipulated that in consideration of the payment of an amount as interest, higher than the normal rate, the lender shall be re-paid his capital in this manner. The borrow-er, after having pald the Interest during the period determined, is free as regards the cap-ital itself. Arg. Fr. Merc. Law, 560

title: Fonsadera
body: In Spanlsh law. Any tribute or loan granted to the king for the purpose of enabling him to defray the expenses of a war

title: Fontana
body: A fountain or spring. Bract, fol. 233

title: Foot
body: 1. A measure of length contain-ing twelve inches or one-third of a yard

title: Foot Of The Fine
body: The fifth part of the conclusion of a flne. It includes the whole matter, reciting the names of the par-ties, day, year, and place, and before whom it was acknowledged or levied. 2 Bl. Comm. 35L

title: Footgeld
body: In the forest law. An amercement for not cutting out the ball or cutting off the claws of a dog’s feet, (exped-itating him.) To be quit of footgeld is to have the privllege of keeping dogs in the for-est unlaiced without punishment or control. Manwood

title: Foot-Prints
body: In the law of evidence. Impressions made upon earth, snow, or other surface by the feet of persons, or by the shoes, boots, or other covering of the feet. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 264

title: Forage
body: Hay and straw for horses, particularly in the army. Jacob

title: Foragium
body: Straw when the corn is threshed out Cowell

title: Foraneus
body: one from without; a foreigner; a stranger. Calvin

title: Forathe
body: In forest law. one who could make oath, i. e., bear wltness for an-other. Cowell; Spelman

title: Forbalca
body: In old records. A fore-balk; a balk (that is, an unplow'ed piece of land) lying forward or next the highway. Cowell

title: Forbannitus
body: A pirate; an outlaw; one banished

title: Forbarrer
body: L. Fr. To bar out; to

title: Forbatudus
body: In old Engllsh law. The aggressor slain in combat Jacob

title: Forbearance
body: The act of abstaining from proceeding against a delinquent debtor; delay in exacting the enforcement of a right; indulgence granted to a debtor. Reynolds v. ward, 5 wend. (N. Y.) 504; Diercks v. Ken-nedy, 16 N. J. Eq. 211; Dry Dock Bank v. American Life Ins., etc., Co., 3 N. Y. 354

title: Force
body: Power dynamically considered, that is, in motion or in action; constraining power, compulsion; strength directed to an end. Usually the word occurs in such connections as to show that unlawful or wrong-ful action is meant, watson v. Railway Co.} 7 Misc. Rep. 562, 28 N. Y. Supp. 84; Plank Road Co. v. Robbins, 22 Barb. (N. Y.)'667

title: Force Majeure
body: RE. Fr. In the law of insurance. Superior or irresistible force. Emerig. Tr. des Ass. c. 12

title: Forced Heirs
body: In Louisiana. Those persons whom the testator or donor cannot deprive of the portion of hia estate reserved for them by law, except in cases where he has a just canse to disinherit them. CivU Code La. art. 1495. And see Crain v. Crain, 17 Tex. 90; Hagerty v. Hagerty, 12 Tex. 456; Miller v. Miller, 105 La. 257, 29 South. 802

title: Forced Sale
body: In practice. A sale made at the time and in the manner pre* scribed by law, in virtue of execution issued on a judgment already rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction; a sale made under the process of the court, and in the mode prescribed by law. Sampson v. williamson, 6 Tex. 110, 55 Am. Dec. 762

title: Forcheapum
body: Pre-emption; forestalling the market. Jacob

title: Forcible Detainer
body: The offense of violently keeping possession of lands and tenements, with menaces, force, and arms, and without the authority of law. 4 Bl. Comm. 148; 4 Steph. Comm. 280

title: Forcible Entry
body: An offense against the public peace, or private wrong, com-mltted by violently taking possession of lands and tenements with menaces, force, and arms, against the will of those entitled to the possession, and without the authority of law. 4 Bl. Comm. 148; 4 Steph. Comm. 280; Code Ga. 1882, | 4524

title: Forcible Entry And Detainer
body: The action of forcible entry and detainer is a summary proceeding to recover possession of premises forcibly or unlawfully detained. The inquiry in such cases does not involve title, but is confined to the actual and peace-able possession of the plaintiff and the un-lawful or forcible ouster or detention hy de-fendant; the object of the law being to pre-vent the disturbance of the public peace by the forcible assertion of a private right. Gore v. Altice, 33 wash. 335, 74 Pac. 556; Eveleth v. Gill, 97 Me. 315, 54 Atl. 757.

title: Forcible Trespass
body: In North Carolina, this is an invasion of the rights of auother with respect to his personal prop-erty, of the same character, or under the same circumstances, which would constitute a “forcible entry and detainer” of real prop-erty at common law. It consists in taking or seizing the personal property of another by force, violence, or intimidation. State v. Lawson, 123 N. C. 740, 31 S. E. 667, 68 Am. St. Rep. 844; State v. Barefoot, 89 N. C. 567; State v. Ray, 32 N. C. 40; State v. Sowls, 61 N. C. 151; State v. Laney, 87 N

title: Forda
body: In old records. A ford or shal-low, made hy damming or penning up the water. Cowell

title: Fordal
body: A butt or headland, jutting out upon other land. Cowell

title: Fordanno
body: In old European law. He who first assaulted another. Spelman

title: Fordika
body: In old records. Grass or herbage growing on the edge or bank of dykes or ditches. Cowell

title: Fore
body: Sax. Before. Fr. out Eel-ham

title: Foreclose
body: To shut out; to bar. Used of the process of destroying an equity of redemption existing in a mortgagor

title: Foreclosure
body: A process in chancery by which all further right existing In a mort-gagor to redeem the estate is defeated and lost to him, and the estate becomes the abso-lute property of the mortgagee; being appli-cable when the mortgagor has forfeited his estate by non-payment of the money due on the mortgage at the time appointed, but still retains the equity of redemption. 2 washb. Real Prop. 237. Goodman v. white, 26 Conn. 322; Arrington v. Liscom, 34 Cal. 376, 94 Am. Dec. 722; Appeal of Ansonia Nat. Bank, 58 Conn. 257. 18 Atl. 1030; willlams v. wilson, 42 or. 299, 70 Pac. 1031, 95 Am. St. Rep 745

title: Forefault
body: In Scotch law. To for* felt; to lose

title: Foregift
body: A premium for a lease

title: Foregoers
body: Royal purveyors. 26 Edw. III. c. 5

title: Forehand Rent
body: In English law

title: Foreign
body: Belonging to another natlon or country; belonging or attached to another jurisdiction; made, done, or rendered in another state or jurisdiction; subject to another jurisdiction; operating or solvable in another territory; extrinsic; outside; extraordinary

title: Foreigner
body: In old English law, this term, when used with reference to a particu-lar city, designated any person who was not an inhabitant of that city. According to lat-er usage, it denotes a person who is not a citizen or subject of the state or country of which mention is made, or any one owing allegiance to a foreign state or sovereign

title: Forein
body: An old form of foreign, (q. v.) Blonnt

title: Forejudge
body: In old English law and practice. To expel from court for some offense or misconduct, when an officer or at-torney of a court was expelled for any offense, or for not appearing to an action by bill filed against him, he was said to be forejudged the court. CowelL

title: Foreman
body: The presiding member of a grand or petit jury, who speaks or answers for the Jury

title: Forensic
body: Belonging to courts of jus-tice

title: Forensis
body: In tbe oivil law. Belonging to or connected with a court; forensic. Forensis homo, an advocate; a pleader of causes; one who practices in conrt Calvin

title: Foreschoke
body: Foresaken; disavowed. 10 Edw. II. c. 1

title: Foreshore
body: That part of the laud ad-Jacent to the sea which is alternately covered and left dry by the ordinary flow of the tides; i. e., by the medium line between the greatest and least range of tide, (spring tides and neap tides.) Sweet

title: Forest
body: In old English law. A certain territory of wooded ground and fruitful pas-tures, privileged for wild beasts and fowls of forest, chase, and warren, to rest and abide in the safe protection of the prince for his princely delight and pleasure, having a peculiar court and officers. Manw. For. Laws, c. 1, no. 1; Termes de la Ley; 1 Bl. Comm. 289

title: Forestagium
body: A duty or tribute pay-able to the king’s foresters. Cowell

title: Forestall
body: To Intercept or obstruct a passenger on the king’s highway. CowelL To beset the way of a tenant so as to prevent his coming on the premises. 3 Bl. Comm. 170. To intercept a deer on his way to the forest before he can regain it Cowell

title: Forestalling The Market
body: The

title: Forestarius
body: In English law. A

title: Forethought Felony
body: In Scotch law. Murder committed in consequence of a previous design. Ersk. lnst. 4, 4, 50; Bell

title: Forfang
body: In old English law.. The taking of provisions from any person in fairs or markets before the royal purveyors were served with necessaries for the sovereign. Cowell. Also the seizing and rescuing of stolen or strayed cattle from the hands of a thief, or of those having illegal possession of them; also the reward fixed for such rescue

title: Forfeit
body: To lose au estate, a franchise, or other property belonging to oue, by tlie act of the law, and ns a consequence of some misfeasance, negligence, or omission. Cassell v. Crothers, 193 Pa. 359, 44 Atl. 446; State v. De Gress, 72 Tex. 242, 11 S. W. 1029; State v. walbrldge, 119 Mo. 383, 24 S. W. 457. 41 Am. St. Rep. 0i>3; State v. Baltimore & O. R. Co., 12 Gill & J. (Md.) 432, 38 Am. Dec. 319. The further ideas connoted by this term are that it is a deprivation, (that is, against the will of the losing iwrty,) aud that tlie property is either transferred to another or resumed by the original grantor

title: Forfeitable
body: Liable to be forfeited; subject to forfeiture for non-user, neglect, crime, etc

title: Forfeiture
body: 1. A punishment annexed by law to some illegal act or negligence

title: Forgavel
body: UM, or FORGAVEL. A

title: Forge
body: To fabricate, construct, or pre-pare one thing iu imitation of another thing, with the intention of substituting tbe false for the genuine, or otherwise deceiving and defraudiug by the use of the spurious article. To counterfeit or make falsely. Especially, to make a spurious written instrument with the intention of fraudulently substituting it for another, or of passing it off as genuine; or to fraudulently alter a genuine instrument to another's prejudice; or to sign another person’s name to a document, with a deceit-ful and frauduleut intent. See In re Cross (D. C.) 43 Fed. 520; U. S. v. watkins, 28 Fed. Cas. 445; Johnson v. State, 9 Tex. App. 251; Longwell v. Day, 1 Mich. N. P. 290; People v. Compton, 123 Cal. 403, 56 Pac. 44.; People v. Graham, 1 Sheld. (N. Y.) 155; Rohr’ v. State, 00 N. J. Law, 576, 38 Atl. 673; Haynes v. State, 15 ohio St. 455; Garner v. State, 5 Lea, 213; State v. Greef.wood, 76 Minn. 211, 78 N. W. 1042. 77 Am. 8t. Rep. 632; State v. Young, 46 N. H. 2«6, 88 Am. Dec. 212

title: Forgery
body: In oriminal law. The

title: Forherda
body: In old records. A herd-land, headland, or foreland. Cowell

title: Fori Disputationes
body: In the clvll law. Discussions or arguments before a court. 1 Kent, Comm. 530

title: Forinsecus
body: Lat Foreign; exterior; outside; extraordinary. Servitium fo-rinsecvm, the payment of aid, scutage, and other extraordinary military services. Fo-rinsecum mancrium, the manor, or that part of it which lies outside the bare or town, and is not included within the liberties of it. Cowell; Blount; Jacob; 1 Reeve, Eng. Law, 273

title: Forinsic
